The ABS orientation and the Witten genus

Jun 8, 2019

Let’s go back to working through our program of trying to construct as a Thom spectrum, namely as the Thom spectrum of a map which detects an indecomposable on the bottom cell of the source. The method of proof is to define a map whose Thom spectrum is also , and is the Anick space. We’d like to think of this as saying that is the twisted smash product . There is a slight issue at ; if I understand correctly, it is not possible for the delooping to exist. For the purpose of this post, let’s pretend as though this is not the case (at least for ), i.e., that there exists a space sitting in a fiber sequence

In the chromatic world, there are interesting spectra which are “smaller” than and detect spherical elements. For instance, when , this is the spectrum , which is conjectural for . At the prime , there are equivalences and . We studied the undoubled version of in this post, where we showed (modulo calculation errors) that it’s not a Thom spectrum.

In light of the equivalence , it is natural to wonder if there are (-)ring spectra and such that and , and and . (Again, means taking the Thom spectrum of a particular map .) Let us focus on for now, and explore the consequences of having such a spectrum.

In this case, there is an equivalence between and the free -algebra , given by the -quotient of the sphere by . OK, so must satisfy the relation . Since and , we take motivation from the EHP sequence

and define to be the -quotient . It is not hard to see that in (there is a emanating from the bottom cell of ), so by the universal property of -quotients, we obtain a map . Including into as its bottom skeleton is , so using the (-)ring structure on , we obtain a map . It is not hard to see that this map is an isomorphism on mod homology, so it is itself an equivalence (after -completion, but that’s what we were implicitly doing anyway). This is also proved in Section 2.5 of this paper, but I didn’t find out about this reference until after I finished this post.

Where do we get the equivalence from? I’ve got no idea (I don’t even know how to do the easier case of , where is replaced with , and we have an -structure), but here is a small piece of evidence. The map is supposed to extend the map detecting the element whose -quotient gets you . At the very least, then, we should be able to find in . But what is ? The bottom few cells of are given by , and is the element detected on the -cell (attached to the -cell by ) lifting via the identity . In other words, is already detected in ; it is the Toda bracket in . So there may be hope for the existence of a map whose Thom spectrum is .

Other than just being conceptually awesome, what’s the point of this result? First, notice that the map is a surjection on homotopy (and that the above result is a spectrification of this statement). We can construct explicit representatives of some of the low-dimensional elements of (and then get the other elements in through multiplication): it is clear that and come from . For the generator of , we notice that the Toda bracket contains and makes sense in . For the generator of , we notice that the Toda bracket contains and makes sense in . (The indeterminacy is for each bracket.)

Next, consider the map ; upon composition with the J-homomorphism, this is sent to the Hopf element . In particular, taking Thom spectra, we find that vanishes in . Since is an -ring, we obtain a map factoring the unit. In particular, composing with the Atiyah-Bott-Shapiro orientation, we obtain -ring maps . Since we showed that the composite is surjective on homotopy, we conclude that the Atiyah-Bott-Shapiro orientation is also surjective on homotopy. Now, we already knew this, of course; in fact, Anderson, Brown, and Peterson proved something stronger: they showed that splits (as a spectrum) off .

This is interesting, because it provides us with a template of what happens for . It’s not known, I think, whether splits off of , but in his ICM address, Mike stated that the Witten genus is surjective on homotopy. Unfortunately, no reference was provided — so we’re going to try to prove this ourselves! Given the discussion above, we have a template of a proof: construct this spectrum as an -ring with some universal property, use this universal property to factor the unit of through , and finally show that the map is surjective on homotopy.

Let’s try to understand . We know that , and since and (additively) , we expect that . Since the homology of the -quotient is and , we expect to be the Thom spectrum of a map . The bottom cell of should detect the lift of (or ?) to coming from the relation .

We now use our favorite trick: noticing that is the Thom spectrum of a map , we find that in order to construct , it suffices to construct an -space sitting in a fiber sequence

and a map detecting on . Since is to be an -space, we need to equivalently construct a space such that there is a fiber sequence

In order to construct such a fiber sequence, we first note that there is a fiber sequence

and so we just need to define a nice map , i.e., an element of . Then is the pullback . According to this table, (and under the boundary map of the fiber sequence above, this maps to the element ), so we choose a generator of this group to obtain our desired fiber sequence defining . It is easy to see that there is a map (which in fact lifts to ), and we define to be the Thom spectrum of this bundle. Moreover, using the fiber sequence involving , we find that , as desired.

To get an equivalence , it suffices to define a map ; since there is a map , the multiplication on defines a map , which is an equivalence on mod homology. Here’s a physics-level-of-rigor argument for the existence of a map . The -skeleton of is given by , so vanishes in . This defines an -ring map . Since is supposed to be the -quotient of (this is where we lose our claim to rigor) by the element in , it suffices to show that the corresponding element vanishes in ; but this again follows from the structure of its -skeleton.

Next, we need to show that there is an equivalence , i.e., that there is a map whose Thom spectrum is . Again, I don’t know how to define such a map since I already can’t yet do this if is replaced by , but we can at least try to show that comes from . The -skeleton of is , and I think that is the lift of to this finite complex.

Anyway, let’s return to our study of the Witten genus. The map which Thomifies to in fact lifts through , and we obtain -ring maps , where the final map is the Witten genus. As with , to prove surjectivity of the Witten genus, it suffices to show that the map is surjective on homotopy. Since (at ) has indecomposable generators in degrees (see here), it suffices to calculate up through dimension and observe that it hits all the indecomposable generators of . (OK, this isn’t exactly right. But I still believe that it is sufficient to look up through dimension ; I’ll try to figure out a proof.) We do this the “old-fashioned” way: look at the Adams spectral sequence! (After all, we know the -comodule structure on .) Here is a picture of the -page of the Adams spectral sequence (using Bruner’s ext program) with some differentials shown for up through dimension (click for a pdf):

And here is a picture of the -page of the Adams spectral sequence with differentials drawn in for up through dimension (click for a pdf):

This obviously isn’t a proof, but the classes in red, blue, and green survive to the -page of the Adams spectral sequence in both charts (and map to each other). The red class in the chart for corresponds to the generator in degree , the blue class corresponds to the generator in degree , and the green class corresponds to the generator in degree . (Edit: this isn’t right! I’ll fix this at some point.) Hopefully I can flesh this out. (Note, of course, that one doesn’t need to work with to show surjectivity of the Witten genus; the interesting part is that is a Thom spectrum with smaller homology than which surjects onto . Of course, the advantage of using is that we know , but we don’t know .)

This raises the question: how can we explicitly construct a -dimensional String-manifold (so ) mapping to the element ? We “know” (scare quotes because of the lack of details in the above discussion) it exists.
